column5:
i guess it depends on your taste for the finer things and spending on 'nightlife'. for a backpacker, $5k (~$330/day) would be a boatload of money. eating street food or casual restaurants and a few beers would cost you about $30-40 at most. transportation and visiting the sights maybe $20-100 depending. leaving you a couple hundred per day which you could spend on nightlife but even that would be extravagant. unless you have super expensive tastes and spend like a drunken sailor on the nightlife, your budget should be more than enough.
i can't speak to how well you'd be accepted as a black male, though the thais are generally very accepting of foreigners. i'd heard that there's been (pre-covid) a criminal element from africa that's makes people wary of black people in general but you'll need to dig deeper on this. as a solo traveler in thailand i found it easy to meet other travelers. it may depend on where you stay, though.
in terms of places to visit, don't miss the fantastic thai temples in bangkok. the temple of the emerald buddha/national palace, wat po, wat arun are some of the most popular. a tour of the klongs in a long tail boat is a must see, imho. if you can, try to make a day trip to ayuthaya for the ruined temples. the floating market is great but couple it with a tour of the surrounding canals.
i haven't been to pattaya in decades but my impression is that it's mostly about the nightlife with little else to do. it's not a great beach destination. imo. others may correct me on this. if you're not married to spending 8 days in pattaya consider splitting the time with koh samui or krabi or phuket. much better beach destinations and still nightlife around.
good luck with your trip!

column5:
i visited thailand in 1989, i went with my grandmother who had lived in phuket or in bhuket as it was known when she lived there in the 1960’s. they lived in phuket town and in 1989 i was lucky to see the house they had lived in and the communal swimming pool my grandfather had helped build. we met my grandparent’s thai friends and it it was an amazing experience for me at aged 17 and for my grandmother to return after over 20 years. as soon as i stepped off the plane it was different to europe, the smells and the noise and the traffic in bangkok. i still clearly remember the journey from the airport into bangkok.
i have a silver cigarette box that was presented to my grandma when she left a thailand as a thank you for teaching the thais scottish country dancing. in 1989 she could not believe that the island she had called the last place on god’s earth was now a destination people called paradise and the number of hotels! a trip to the beach in the 1960s was a journey along bumpy roads, there were no hotels. i spent an amazing 5 weeks starting in bangkok, visiting pattaya, phuket, penang and kl, ending in singapore.
it was such an enjoyable trip that we returned in 1998 with my grandma and husband. her house in phuket was now inhabited and the communal pool empty. i would love to find out the exact location. my husband and i loved our trip, sadly we lost my grandma in 1999. it was a delightful surprise when my brother announced he was moving to bangkok in 2001 to teach for a few months, he intended to move onto japan and other countries, 20 years later he is still in bangkok and is now married with two children. we have managed to visit twice with our kids and once on our own and now hope to visit every year. last february was our first winter trip which was absolutely amazing to get away from the cold weather. can’t wait to be able to return and think it will be an annual winter trip for us.

indeed, in normal years i usually reserve kyoto hotels at least 5 months in advance, especially for sakura blossoms. another option is to stay in osaka and commute to kyoto daily in about 1 hour. however, the later you book the higher the hotel rates (when cheaper rooms have been snatched up) and possibly in less convenient locations.

column5:
often with air travel people tend to think of the flight itself which might be 1 or 2 hours, but with international trips it will generally take at least 6 hours altogether when you factor in all the movements - checking out of hotel, getting to airport (at least 2 hours before flight time), then the flight, then getting to the next hotel, and if too early you might not be able to check in yet... so really you lose the best part of a day. it's not like europe where you can often switch cities by train and sleep on the way.
even domestic flights, you lose a fair chunk of time. so if you want to go to 3 places in thailand and 2 in malaysia, plus 2 international locations in a 3 week trip... it's a lot of time wasted in transit. my own rule of thumb from my experience in se asia is 1 city each 5 days maximum.
also personally, if wanting to relax at a beach location, in my opinion you need 6 or 7 nights minimum, to really get the relaxation benefit.
just my own opinion .. i'd go to penang in malaysia for about 4 days, then bangkok 3 days, chiang mai 5 days then the rest at a beach location.

whilst the location of the amwaj is great, it’s all inclusive is limited, when i stayed their all inclusive had just launched and it only cost me £60 ( that was total for 3 of us for 4 nights) to upgrade from b&b to ai so it was a no brainer as it equated to £5 pp per day!
however those who had booked several months later paid significantly more and in my opinion i’d have been very disappointed if i’d paid top money. drinks are limited (no cocktails) and whilst the food is nice your choices again are somewhat limited.
i couldn’t complain as i got my money back on the first day in soft drinks alone but unless it was an absolute bargain again, i wouldn’t opt for all inclusive in this hotel or when staying in this area.
i’ve stayed at palm tree court half a dozen times but not for a couple of years, i have heard it’s got slightly more restrictive recently however when i’ve stayed it offers the most extensive choice of restaurants and food is really good quality, it’s out of town and is a resort in itself.
rixos - stayed twice, once b&b on a short stay and another fine ai. i prefer the rooms and resort to ptc as it’s more modern and in my opinion has a nicer pool area. the food is very good but i don’t think it’s quite as good as ptc and the choice isn’t as extensive but the buffet is decent as is are the drinks quality and variety. even though it’s the furthest hotel out on the palm it feels less far out than ptc .
personally i’d opt for the cheapest between ptc and rixos as they’re both excellent.
as for riu, i haven’t stayed, nor do i intend to but it’s 4* and i suspect it’ll be more limited on the food & drinks package than ptc or rixos.

column5:
andrew, while nusa dua might offer you the type of hotel you are after, you may find yourselves bored witless if you spend 2 weeks there. as advised, it's basically a manufactured resort area with not much to offer. and if you really do go ai, then you'll be stuck at your hotel day in, day out, eating at the same places/same menus for the whole time. as long as you are aware of this of course, and just want a holiday where you sit on the beach or around the pool for the two weeks, then this idea may be perfectly fine for you.
you have also been advised about travel times in bali. and nusa dua is a long way from most of the interesting things to do and see. as an example, if you wanted to do/see anything around ubud, then allow 3-4 hours in the car to get there and back. that means you'll be missing the meals you have paid for back at your hotel. as well as sitting in a car travelling the same roads you have already travelled.
most people who go to bali do not stay in one area for two weeks, many visit 2-3 parts of bali, to experience the island more fully.
you also may like to reconsider hiring a car to go off exploring. driving in bali is not for the feint hearted. roads are narrow, not signposted and traffic is more than horrendous. most of us do use a driver with car and arrange our day trips. cost is around 600,000 idr per car, not per person and you can discuss with your driver the things you want to see. however, if you book at your hotel in nd, then expect to pay a whole lot more than this. also do beware of set "tours" which often charge per person.
can i suggest that you do a whole lot more research, and decide what you really want from your honeymoon. bali has so very much to offer, that it would be a shame not to see any of it while you were there. you could start by reading about the areas of bali, link below. also, on a computer (not phone) read the top questions about bali, right hand side of the bali forum front page
whatever you decide, i hope you have a wonderful honeymoon.

column5:
>> any recommendations to areas to stay kerala sound nice? <<
kerala has several places well worth staying - depending on how long you are staying you might choose a couple.
northern kerala has a string of coastal villages and some lovely beaches which are less visited that those in southern kerala. kannur might be a good option for you.
in central kerala: fort cochin - first and foremost - is a calm spot with plenty of visitor attractions at hand. there are also beaches in this part of the state - cherai and marari for example.
southern kerala: a couple of beach destinations - one at kovalam the other at varkala. also, the joy of kerala is a couple of nights on a houseboat from alleppey.
the western ghats - a mountain range - offer the alternative to coastal life - this region has plenty of national parks, wildlife sanctuaries, trekking and spice, coffee and tea plantations.

quarantine is a proper medical quarantine, not some casual self-isolation. the only person that can share a room is your legally married spouse (or your children). the hotels require copies of passports for all guests staying in advance and need proof (copy of wedding license) for couples.
you can not get adjoining rooms and open the doors. they even lock balcony doors if there is not a solid physical partition between balconies.
but no, you will not be put on a plane if you cheat during quarantine, rather you will have to pay the full asq amount again, start your quarantine from day 0 and pay quarantine expenses for anyone you come in contact with.

column5:
you’re better off taking the hit and staying in dubai.
rak isn’t in dubai, it’s a completely different emirate and whilst brochures and agents might try and sell it as being in close proximity it’s worth remembering that dubai is very spread out and it might take several hours to get from
parts of rak to some parts of dubai.
whilst rak has a number of all inclusive hotels that are popular there isn’t much at all to see in rak and many of the hotels are quite remote, it’s more geared towards people who are wanting to stay in resort.
given you were looking to go to nyc & vegas i’m guessing sightseeing and a livelier holiday is what you had in mind so i’d definitely recommend dubai.
dubai hotels are more expensive than rak if you’re looking for ‘like for like’ however there are several all inclusive hotels in dubai alternatively just opt for b&b or hb and stay somewhere more central, take advantage of drinks promotions and ladies nights ( where you get free or discounted drinks) which will be ideal given you’re travelling with your mum.
although dubai isn’t renowned for being a cheap destination, the last time i was in nyc i thought prices there had risen dramatically and at least in dubai it is possible to have a cheaper night out! ladies nights are the way to go as it’s possible to find somewhere almost every night of the week where they have drinks promotions on.

thai weddings and western weddings are quite different. for one, there is usually no officiant at the ceremony, it is more of a family exchange of blessings, dowry, some blessing by monks perhaps, and then partyyyyy. all the officiating functions are done at city hall.

column5:
i cut things short in the end, in part because of the weather (and it being too cold to camp !), and in part because i've got through most of the things i wanted to do anyway.
actual itinerary was vaguely as below:
day 0 - travel up to inverness
day 1 - bus to ullapool, ferry to stornoway, pick up hire car, drive to harris. wild camped (freezing).
day 2 - looking about harris. slept in the eagle observatory hut (probably even more freezing than the tent).
day 3 - ferry to berneray. quick look round berneray, drive round a few places in the uists, b&b in benbecula.
day 4- banranland and griminish point (swam in the sea :) brrrr ), b&b on benbecula
day 5 - walked a few holes at askernish golf course, had a look around eriskay including walking up the biggest hill, b&b on benbecula
day 6 - ferry to skye. walked up to an around old man of storr. b&b in broadford.
day 7 - drove to the lochalsh peninsula on the mainland, and down to armissdale and corron where i went for a wee walk, before getting the tiny wee ferry back over from glenelg to skye. checked out the otter hide. drove to elgol and walked around a bit. walked from camasunary car park up to the top. drove to portree for a look around. drove to dungevan and camped.
day 8 - walked the loop at the quirang, beating a major snowstorm by minutes. had a quick peek at the kilted cliff, found a nice b&b in portree.
day 9 - ferry back to harris. quick walk on luskentyre beach before heading up to lewis to check out uig sands, kneep, the callindish stones, and a few other stops along the way
day 10 - cleaned the car out and returned it before getting a glorious ferry ride back to ullapool which was bathed in beautiful sunshine. hotel in inverness.
day 11 - early train home
distance driven : 1002 miles.
highlights:
- the walk to traigh na cleavag from northton (harris)
- balranald & griminish point (benbecula)
- the quirang and old man of storr (skye)
trip costs (excluding gear for camping (haha) and hiking):
- car hire and fuel £440
- other transport (trains, buses, ferries) £350
- accommodation £ 520
- living expenses and other costs £250
total £1,560
photos to follow.

the rate has slightly gone up recently and is hovering around dhs 5 to £1gbp.
beach passes differ, some include money back of food & beverage others don’t. it depends on how quiet the hotel is. either way i’d always opt for a day pass over hiring beds on the beach. it’s a far more luxurious experience and often works out the same or cheaper cost wise.
i’ve done many a day visit to suss out a hotel to see if it’s a potential one for a future visit
there’s also beach clubs, some have free entry or offers on ladies days but naturally they’re busier. avoid friday & saturday’s as they can be busy and generally charge more for access.
if you look on time out nearer your time of travel it can list offers for beach passes. if not the internet is equally as useful.
